questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the Direction property of an Indicator?

discussion.content:
The purpose of the Direction property of an Indicator is:

D. Indicates whether scores should ideally increase or decrease

This property is used to define the expected or desired trend for the indicator's scores over time, helping to quickly assess whether changes in the indicator's scores are moving in a positive or negative direction according to the defined goals.

choices.C: if ([[Number of resolved incidents]] == 0) {0} else ([[Number of resolved incidents]])

choices.A: ((Number of new critical incidents)) / ((Number of new incidents)) * 100

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct, check this Formula indicator in a PDI Instance: % new high risk changes

Selected Answer: A
Given answer is correct.

Accordingly to the documentation (https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/washingtondc-now-intelligence/page/use/performance-analytics/concept/c_ExcludingBreakdownsFromFormulas.html) it is possible to use curly brackets, which will not follow breakdowns for the whole formula indicator.

Example given on docs:
'You can still specify a breakdown and element for a contributing indicator that does not follow breakdowns for the whole formula indicator. Consider the formula [[Incidents]] / {{Customers > importance = high}}. In this example, the formula denominator is always broken down to include only the high-importance customers. Any breakdown applied to the formula indicator, such as the region breakdown, does not apply to the Customers indicator.'

The syntactically incorrect formula, given that all indicator names are valid, is:

D. [[Number of new incidents]] / {{Number of new incidents}} * 100

The use of double curly braces {{}} is incorrect syntax for referencing indicators or constants in Performance Analytics formulas. Indicators should be referenced with double square brackets [[]], and constants don't typically require any special brackets in this context.

questions.question_text: Which Indicator should you exclude from a Historic Data Collection because its scores cannot be accurately collected?

discussion.content:
You should exclude from a Historic Data Collection any indicator whose score is inherently dependent on the current date and time, as its scores cannot be accurately back-collected or recreated historically. Among the options provided:

D. Summed age of open problems

This indicator would be difficult to collect historically with accuracy because it depends on the current date relative to the open date of the problems, which would constantly be changing. Historic data collection would not be able to recreate past 'summed ages' accurately.

Selected Answer: B
B. Number of open problems not updated in last 90 days
Tested in my PDI, this is the only indicator that das not have a Historical Job associated with it
